results.title: Animals: ways they move
results.brief_description: Illustrates how animals move in water, on land and in the air. Explains that an animal’s movement helps it to acquire food, to protect itself from enemies, to find a home, to move from place to place, and to adapt to its environment.
results.description: Illustrates how animals move in water, on land and in the air. Explains that an animal’s movement helps it to acquire food, to protect itself from enemies, to find a home, to move from place to place, and to adapt to its environment.

results.title: Animals of the zoo
results.brief_description: A visit to a zoo at feeding time, provides an opportunity to study the food and eating habits of various animals: lion, tiger, gorilla, chimpanzee, eland, bison, black and polar bears. Also contains a rare short sequence of a Tasmanian tiger, referred to as a wolf dog. Habitats and characteristics of each are described.

results.title: Animals of the rocky shore [B&W]
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Gaumont-British Instructional and Scottish Marine Biological Station
results.brief_description: This film is a simple ecological study of animals whose structure and habits enable them to live on rocky shores both above and below the low-tide mark. The following animals are seen: the common starfish, brittle star, sea urchin, sea stickleback and gobies, the swimming crab, the whelk, the hermit crab (seen climbing into a shell), sea anenomes, polyp clava, and the sea-aquirt ciona. Between tide-marks on the exposed rock surface, mussels, limpets, winkles, and acorn barnacles are seen. The whole series of animals is related to problems of life on the rocky shore.

results.title: Animals of Australia
results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: An overview of Australian animals, grouped according to their natural habitat - the dry inland, open forests, rain forests and coastal areas. Both well known and lesser known animals are seen. Elementary descriptive treatment. Suitable for primary school level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia

results.title: Animals in winter
results.creator_credit: Heinz Sielmann and Heinz Sielmann Productions
results.brief_description: The behaviour in winter of squirrels, hamsters, insects, frogs, butterflies and other creatures, showing how they cope with the rigours of cold and the shortage of food in order to survive until the spring. Intended for primary and secondary schools

results.title: Animals in modern life
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: Deals with the wide variety of uses to which animals are put in our modern civilisation - to furnish food, clothing materials, and power. Shows how animals have been domesticated and now, while power uses of animals are decreasing, more and more are being used for food and for clothing.

results.title: Animals and how they communicate
results.brief_description: By sight, sound and movement, animals communicate fear, presence, interest, alarm and many other aspects of behaviour. A wide range of examples from courtship displays among birds, to the social life of prairie dogs and the intricate actions of bees and ants illustrate role of communication in animal life and survival. No other credits available.

results.title: Animals and their homes
results.brief_description: Various animal homes are evaluated as places for rearing young, in terms of protection afforded by environment, location, and building materials. The duck, grebe, beaver, stickle-back, rabbit, horned lark, robin, eagle, squirrel, gopher, prairie dog, wasp and cliff swallow are shown and discussed.

results.title: Animals and their foods
results.brief_description: To illustrate that animals are suited to eating different foods, the film shows animals that eat plants, some that eat meat, and others that eat both. It is explained that wild animals must search for food and all animals need food to live and grow.

results.brief_description: This animated film traces the history and development of lubricants from the time of the Egyptians to the present day.
